Commanding in Chief, Fighter Command, in regard to air raid(Previous warnings. In this letter it was explained that an intermediateReference: signal was being devised which would have the significance of aW.M. (40) 183rd red warning so far as concerned, e.g., the extinguishing of lightsConclusions, in docks and marshalling yards, but would not involve the sounding-Minute l.) of sirens. Sir Hugh Dowding thought, however, that if it was intended to discontinue warning the public at large of anapproaching raid, they would expect an announcement explaining the change in policy. The lines which such an announcement might follow were sketched out.The Minister without Portfolio explained that, in accordancewith the War Cabinet's decision on the previous Wednesday, hehad discussed this matter with the Minister of Home Security andwith the Supply Ministers. A Report had been prepared setting out the recommendations made at this meeting for improving thepresent system. This Report had not yet been finally approved bythe Ministers concerned, but he hoped to be able to circulate it early on the following morning.The War Cabinet Deferred further consideration of this question, pendingsubmission of the Minister without Portfolio's Report.France. 3. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs read a telegram,French forces in dated the 30th June, from the Consul-General at Tunis addressedTunis. to the Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean. The Consul-Generalreported that he had been approached by officers of the ForeignLegion at Susa with a view to embarking 1,800 legionaires. Therewere also two French submarines at Susa whose attitude was saidto be favourable.The War Cabinet thought that the best plan would probablybe that these 1,800 legionaires should be taken to Palestine.The War Cabinet-(1) Gave instructions that this telegram should be brought tothe notice of the First Lord of the Admiralty and theSecretary of State for War. Subject to the latter's views,the First Lord of the Admiralty was invited to ask theCommander-in-Chief, Mediterranean, if he could arrange to transport these troops to Palestine.(2) Invited the First Lord of the Admiralty to take such steps as he might consider appropriate to induce these twTosubmarines to transfer their allegiance to us.
